docs.snippet: Gov. George E. Pataki capped off a frenzied week playing host to the Republican National Convention by introducing President Bush on Thursday night....
docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki capped off a frenzied week playing host to the Republican National Convention by introducing President Bush last night and lighting into his old Yale acquaintance John Kerry as ''a candidate who has to Google his own name to find where he stands.'' In a week that saw the governor hopping from delegate breakfasts to late-night parties, Mr. Pataki was able to leave behind the pressing troubles of his state government, which remains hopelessly gridlocked on major issues. And last night he capped it all off with a convention speech that somberly recalled Sept. 11, introduced the president and incidentally introduced himself to national Republicans, whom he hopes to woo as he sets the stage for a possible presidential run in 2008.

headline.main: Pataki's Speech Caps a Week of Parties and Promotion
headline.kicker: THE REPUBLICANS: THE CONVENTION IN NEW YORK -- THE GOVERNOR

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki caps frenzied week playing host to Republican National Convention by introducing Pres Bush; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Skype is the easiest, fastest and cheapest way for individual customers to use their computers with broadband connections as telephones....
docs.lead_paragraph: HOW big a deal will Skype turn out to be? I have no idea whether the company itself, which was founded one year ago, will someday come to epitomize and dominate a particular booming business, the way Google, eBay and Amazon now do. But I feel confident that the service it provides will be attractive to most people who give it a serious look. Skype, a made-up term that rhymes with ''tripe,'' is the most popular and sexiest application of VoIP, which doesn't rhyme with anything. VoIP -- sometimes pronounced letter by letter, like C.I.A., and at other times as a word -- stands for voice over Internet protocol. Essentially, it is a way of allowing a computer with a broadband connection to serve as a telephone.

headline.main: In Internet Calling, Skype Is Living Up to the Hype

docs.snippet: AOL, home of some avid online shoppers, is adding features to make its browsing and buying easier....
docs.lead_paragraph: COMPARISON shopping Web sites like Yahoo Shopping, Google's Froogle and Shopping.com are about to face some new competition from an old online player. Next Monday, America Online, the Internet division of Time Warner, will introduce a shopping Web site called In-Store.com to go along with the company's revamped shopping section. It will be AOL's first offering to consumers who want to research products side by side before buying.

headline.main: AOL, home of some avid online shoppers, is adding features to make their browsing and buying easier.

docs.abstract: America Online to offer new shopping Web site, In-Store, that will include elements of both traditional online shopping mall and comparison shopping engine as part of its revamped shopping section; site will let consumers research products side by side before buying; consumers have yet to fully embrace comparison shopping; graph of comparison sites (M)

docs.snippet: Amazon.com, the e-commerce giant, plans to take aim at the Internet search king Google with an advanced technology that the company says will take searches beyond mere retrieval of Web pages to let users more fully manage the information they find...
docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the e-commerce giant, plans to take aim at the Internet search king Google with an advanced technology that the company says will take searches beyond mere retrieval of Web pages to let users more fully manage the information they find. A9.com, a start-up owned by Amazon, said in a briefing here on Tuesday that it planned to make the new version of its search service, named A9.com, available Tuesday evening. The service will offer users the ability to store and edit bookmarks on an A9.com central server computer, keep track of each link clicked on previous visits to a Web page, and even make personal ''diary'' notes on those pages for viewing on subsequent visits.

headline.main: Amazon to Take Searches On Web to a New Depth

docs.abstract: Amazon.com plans to take aim at Google with advanced technology that company says will take Internet searches beyond mere retrieval of Web pages to let users more fully manage information they find; A9.com, start-up owned by Amazon, plans to make new version of its search service named A9.com available evening of Sept 15; service will offer users ability to store and edit bookmarks on A9.com central server computer, keep track of each link clicked on previous visits to Web page, and even make personal 'diary' notes on those pages for viewing on subsequent visits; A9.com chief executive Udi Manber, who created original A9 search service, comments; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Sharon Love, president at the Promotion Network, Dallas, part of the Omnicom Group, was promoted to chief executive, succeeding Roger Winter, who becomes chairman. Ms. Love will continue to be based in the New York office. Rich Feitler, executive ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sharon Love, president at the Promotion Network, Dallas, part of the Omnicom Group, was promoted to chief executive, succeeding Roger Winter, who becomes chairman. Ms. Love will continue to be based in the New York office. Rich Feitler, executive vice president, was promoted to president, succeeding Ms. Love. He will continue to be based in the Chicago office.
docs.abstract: Sharon Love, president at Promotion Network, is promoted to chief executive, succeeding Roger Winter, who becomes chairman; executive vice president Richard Feitler is promoted to president, succeeding Love; Penry Price is named Eastern sales director at New York office of Google, new post (S)

docs.snippet: Wall Street, which forced Google, the Internet search engine, to lower the price of its shares sharply in its initial public offering in August, has decided that the company is worth a lot more today than it was then....
docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street, which forced Google, the Internet search engine, to lower the price of its shares sharply in its initial public offering in August, has decided that the company is worth a lot more today than it was then. Research analysts associated with five of the investment banks that managed Google's offering released their first reports on the company yesterday, at the end of a government-mandated quiet period.

headline.main: Google Shares, Once Devalued, Just May Be Winners After All

docs.abstract: Research analysts associated with five investment banks that managed Google's initial stock offering in August and forced it to lower offering price sharply release their first reports on company after required quiet period, valuing shares at more than 50 percent above offering price; stock price graph (M)

docs.snippet: Vivisimo, an Internet search engine company, is introducing a service that is meant to lessen online information overload....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google executives have long conceded that one of their great fears is to be overtaken by a more advanced Internet search technology. Vivisimo, a company founded by three former Carnegie Mellon University computer scientists, is hoping to prove that Google's worries are well founded. Four-year-old Vivisimo plans to start Clusty, a free, consumer search service based on results from Yahoo's Overture engine, Thursday.

headline.main: New Company Starts Up A Challenge To Google

docs.abstract: Vivismo plans to start Clusty, free, Internet consumer search service based on results from Yahoo's Overture engine; already offers search service for corporate customers, which clusters results into categories to make them easier to sort through; Clusty, which will be supported by advertising revenue, uses similar organizational structure; also presents series of tabs enabling user to see results from sources besides general Web; many search experts say clustering offers better way of looking at data than Google's page-ranking system (M)
